Constructing truncated Brown-Peterson spectra

Feb 16, 2019

We would like to construct an form of , in the sense of Lawson-Naumann. At the prime , this is given by , and at the prime , there is a construction using the full Atkin-Lehner quotient of the Shimura curve of discriminant . In this post, we discuss some desiderata of an algebro-geometric construction of .

Fix a prime and ; then, define . Then, there is a gap in the homotopy of : we have for . Moreover, there is an element (the dualizing class, which comes from Anderson duality) in degree , such that there is a perfect pairing

In the case of , we know that , and ; then, the dualizing element is described in this document.

We would like to construct an even-periodic refinement of a flat map from a proper (so that, with a few additional assumptions, has a dualizing element) Noetherian Deligne-Mumford stack such that . In all known cases where such a model of is known (i.e., at ), the descent spectral sequence collapses at the -page: in other words,

and by duality (discussed above) we have . In particular:

  • we need there to be an isomorphism ; and
  • by Serre duality, it is most natural to ask for to be a smooth and proper (stacky) curve. Since would have cohomological dimension one, this implies that the descent spectral sequence degenerates at the -page, which explains Equation .

If we assume that is a smooth and proper curve, then we claim that is a dualizing sheaf on if it is ample. To show this, we argue as in here. Indeed, since satisfies Anderson duality, we have , which implies that . Since , we know that is always odd; let us write . Then, there are isomorphisms

so we can choose the element corresponding to . Then, the pairing in Equation shows that there is a perfect pairing

If is ample, then we find that is a dualizing sheaf on ; in particular, it is isomorphic to the standard dualizing sheaf . We need to show that this implies that is a dualizing sheaf on ; for this, it suffices to show that the map is injective. This is a consequence of Proposition II.6.5 of Hartshorne.

In light of the above discussion, we now assume that is a smooth and proper curve such that is ample, so that is the dualizing sheaf of . Then has Kodaira dimension ; equivalently, must be of genus zero. Since , we find that . If we assume that is of genus zero, then is isomorphic to a weighted projective stack . Since the Picard group of is isomorphic to , and the dualizing sheaf of is , it follows that ; in particular, because for every prime , we conclude that is isomorphic to , since . Ampleness is immediate.

There are a few natural candidates of genus zero curves which carry a formal group: these are modular curves and (quotients of) Shimura curves. For a general modular curve, there is an open subvariety of containing the supersingular points which carries a -divisible group of height such that the associated map is formally etale. We conclude that is isomorphic to the product of , as ranges over the -isomorphism classes of supersingular points of . Since , we need there to be only one such supersingular point. This leads to the following list of natural desiderata to impose on :

  1. is a smooth and proper stacky curve of genus zero (recall that the genus zero requirement is equivalent to being ample, as proved above.); and
  2. there is only one -isomorphism class of points on such that the associated -dimensional formal group is of height .

The genus zero requirement already tells us that it is futile to use modular curves or (quotients of) Shimura curves to prove the existence of an -form of at all primes: there are only finitely many such curves of genus zero (for instance, the modular curve is of genus zero if and ). In the case of modular curves, the restriction on the height of the formal group simply says that there needs to be only one -isomorphism class of supersingular elliptic curves. In the case of Shimura curves parametrizing abelian surfaces along with a nondegenerate action as described above, this condition states that there needs to be only one -isomorphism class of such pairs for which splits as the sum of a multiplicative and etale -divisible group, i.e., , and hence , is ordinary. (This is a rather strange requirement to impose, because the locus of ordinary abelian varieties is dense and open; however, we are saved since we also allow for quotients of Shimura curves. For instance, if we quotient out by the group of the Atkin-Lehner involutions, then the requirement then states that the locus of ordinary abelian surfaces is contained inside a single -orbit. Nonetheless, this condition forces the resulting curve to be rather “small”.)

In fact, by work of Lawson-Naumann, only one additional condition (descending along the canonical subgroup) is needed to guarantee that the connective cover of the global sections of an even-periodic refinement of satisfying the conditions listed above is an -form of . It’d be very nice to know of examples where this is true.
